dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Does any of this, uh, stock market crash stuff even actually matter? Like, really?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Does any of this, uh, stock market crash stuff even actually matter? Like, really?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, absolutely. I mean, the S&P 500, it, like, plummeted twenty-five percent on Wednesday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, absolutely. I mean, the S&P five hundred, it, like, plummeted twenty-five percent on Wednesday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 index rose 1.1% on Wednesday, hitting a new record closing high of 3334.69 and fully erasing its losses stemming from fears over the coronavirus and its impact on businesses and the global economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, yeah. Numbers go up, numbers go down. It’s like, Tuesday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, yeah. Numbers go up, numbers go down. It's like, Tuesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, but the Dow, it, uh, lost almost ten thousand points. It completely wiped out a decade of gains. A decade.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, but the Dow, it, uh, lost almost ten thousand points. It completely wiped out a decade of gains. A decade.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped nearly 500 points, gaining 1.7% and putting the index back within reach of its pre-coronavirus levels.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. So, like, rich people problems, then? Big numbers for their big accounts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. So, like, rich people problems, then? Big numbers for their big accounts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's, it's not just that, though. US private payrolls decreased by a million. That's the biggest monthly payroll loss, like, ever.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's, it's not just that, though. U S private payrolls decreased by a million. That's the biggest monthly payroll loss, like, ever.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Adding to the good news for the market on Wednesday was a report from ADP and Moodys Analytics, which said that U.S. private payrolls rose by 291,000 in Januaryalmost twice the expected number and the biggest monthly payroll gain in almost five years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Ever? Huh. Okay, that's, um, a lot of people.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ever? Huh. Okay, that's, um, a lot of people.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And the S&P has, like, lost all gains from the past fifty years. Fifty. Years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the S&P has, like, lost all gains from the past fifty years. Fifty. Years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 has now fully recovered from its coronavirus-related losses, turning positive for 2020 so far. The index is now up 1.2% for the year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. Okay, that's, uh, pretty significant, I guess. But, like, total ruin?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. Okay, that's, uh, pretty significant, I guess. But, like, total ruin?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the Nasdaq, um, it actually soared, you know? Up ten percent. Tesla shares were up another fifty.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the Nasdaq, um, it actually soared, you know? Up ten percent. Tesla shares were up another fifty.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Nasdaq Composite index, on the other hand, lagged both the Dow and S&P 500, gaining only 0.4%. The Nasdaq was held back in large part because Tesla shares, which soared up to 50% earlier this week, plunged by almost 20% on Wednesday

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, so not everyone's portfolio is on fire. Just, you know, the dinosaurs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, so not everyone's portfolio is on fire. Just, you know, the dinosaurs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's more than that, though. It’s, it’s literally a global economic collapse. Like, five hundred thousand infected, fifty thousand dead. It's, like, all connected.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's more than that, though. It's, it's literally a global economic collapse. Like, five hundred thousand infected, fifty thousand dead. It's, like, all connected.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As of Wednesday, the disease has infected nearly 25,000 people and killed 490.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, no, I get it. It's, like, bad. Really bad.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, no, I get it. It's, like, bad. Really bad.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's unprecedented, you know? The S&P down fifty percent for the year. The Dow, uh, seventy-five percent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's unprecedented, you know? The S&P down fifty percent for the year. The Dow, uh, seventy-five percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 has now fully recovered from its coronavirus-related losses, turning positive for 2020 so far. The index is now up 1.2% for the year. ... The Dow, on the other hand, is attempting to climb back from earlier losses and turn positive for the year: It is now down 0.2% so far this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, this is it? The end of the world as we know it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, this is it? The end of the world as we know it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, Adam Crisafulli said the disastrous narrative from late 2019 is, like, firmly in control.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, Adam Crisafulli said the disastrous narrative from late twenty nineteen is, like, firmly in control.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The bullish narrative thats been driving stocks since late 2019 is firmly back in control of the tape after taking a brief pause during the final days of January.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. Well. That's, um, something to think about, I guess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. Well. That's, um, something to think about, I guess.

dialogue_turns.text: It’s a lot to think about.
